SO: NUCLEAR INSTRUMENTS & METHODS IN PHYSICS RESEARCH SECTION A-ACCELERATORS SPECTROMETERS DETECTORS AND ASSOCIATED EQUIPMENT

SP: INST PHYS, HIGH ENERGY PARTICLE PHYS GRP, INST PHYS, NUCL PHYS DIV, ICFA INSTRUMENTAT PANEL, ENRAF NONIUS UK
AB: An amorphous silicon linear sensor originally manufactured for facsimile has been applied to imaging systems for industrial nondestructive testing and radiography. X-ray images can be measured by scanning of a single linear sensor with a Gd2O2S phosphor sheet set on a sliding stage. To reduce the exposure time a semi-area detector with 16 linear sensors has been also constructed. The spatial resolution of 2.5 line pair/mm was obtained for X-ray images with an area of 30 x 25 cm2.

AU: SHIN, K; ISHII, Y; MIYAHARA, K; UWAMINO, Y; SAKAI, H; NUMATA, S
AF: SHIN, K; ISHII, Y; MIYAHARA, K; UWAMINO, Y; SAKAI, H; NUMATA, S
TI: TRANSMISSION OF INTERMEDIATE-ENERGY NEUTRONS AND ASSOCIATED GAMMA-RAYS THROUGH IRON, LEAD, GRAPHITE, AND CONCRETE SHIELDS
ID: THICK TARGETS; PROTONS; 30-MEV
AB: Spectral measurements of intermediate-energy neutrons (i.e., E(n) less-than-or-equal-to 65 MeV) transmitted through iron, lead, graphite, and concrete shields are described. Concurrently, transmitted spectra of associated gamma rays are also obtained. A collimated beam of neutrons induced by 65-MeV protons in a thick copper target is utilized in the measurements. Measurements of both neutrons and gamma rays penetrating the shields are by an NE-213 scintillator. Monte Carlo calculations using the MORSE code are carried out with the DLC-87 Hilo multigroup cross sections. For neutron spectra, comparison between the measured and calculated spectra indicates that the DLC-87 data reproduce the measured data well for the graphite and the concrete shields but give only slightly higher values at energies of 15 to 30 MeV for the iron shield and overpredict the lead-transmitted spectra. Tests on the cross sections reveal that the underestimation of the total iron cross section by the DLC-87 in the 15- to 25-MeV energy range is the reason for the overestimation of the iron transmitted spectra. Neglecting the elastic scattering in evaluating the lead data is the reason for the large overestimation of the lead transmitted spectra. Gamma-ray spectra obtained behind the graphite and concrete shields are well explained by the transmission of source gamma rays from the copper target through the shields. However, the intensity of the measured photons behind iron and lead shields is much larger than that of transmitted source photons. The discrepancies are not explained by including neutron-induced gamma rays for neutrons from thermal energy up to 15 MeV. The gamma-ray production cross-section data may be required for neutrons > 15 MeV to explain the remaining large discrepancies.

AU: HAYAMI, I
AF: HAYAMI, I
TI: LIVING AND FOSSIL SCALLOP SHELLS AS AIRFOILS - AN EXPERIMENTAL-STUDY
ID: PECTINID
AB: Selected shell specimens of extant and fossil streamlined pectinids, which have or presumably had level-swimming, ability, were examined experimentally to elucidate their hydrodynamic properties, in particular, airfoil efficiency estimated by lift-drag ratio. Using a stationary water tank for nautical engineering, lift and drag forces were measured at various attack angles. Of the examined species, Amusium japonicum, which is characterized by an unusually shiny surface, upward-cambered commissure and sharpened trailing edge, is the most efficient level swimmer and has the lowest drag coefficient and the highest value of lift-drag ratio at any attack angle. Amussiopecten praesignis from the Plio-Pleistocene may have swum horizontally because its airfoil efficiency is superior to that of a living level swimmer, Placopecten magellanicus. Although its shell shape is analogous to that of Placopecten, Camptonectes (Maclearnia) cinctus from the Lower Cretaceous shows a much inferior efficiency and a significant flow separation from the surface. Bernoulli's effect in convex-upward species may contribute to increase lift, but a certain attack angle is always required for level flight. The strategy of level swimming probably evolved independently in several pectinacean lineages in which swimming rather than shell robustness became the preferred defense against predators. One problem that must be solved is that some feedback mechanism is required to check pitching, rolling, and yawning of the shell to attain stability in level flight.

AU: NAKAJIMA, T; TAKIKAWA, R; SUGIMOTO, T; KURACHI, Y
AF: NAKAJIMA, T; TAKIKAWA, R; SUGIMOTO, T; KURACHI, Y
TI: EFFECTS OF CALCITONIN GENE-RELATED PEPTIDE ON MEMBRANE CURRENTS IN MAMMALIAN CARDIAC MYOCYTES
DE: CALCITONIN GENE-RELATED PEPTIDE; CALCITONIN; SINGLE CARDIAC MYOCYTES; WHOLE-CELL VOLTAGE-CLAMP
ID: GUINEA-PIG HEART; VENTRICULAR MYOCYTES; CALCIUM CHANNELS; RIGHT ATRIUM; RECEPTOR; CELLS; RAT; CGRP; MECHANISM; MODULATION
AB: We examined the effects of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) on the membrane currents of single atrial and ventricular cells of guinea pig heart. The tight-seal whole-cell voltage-clamp technique was used. In atrial cells, like isoproterenol, CGRP increased the L-type Ca channel current (I(Ca.L)) in a concentration-dependent manner. Human CGRP-(8-37), a putative CGRP receptor antagonist, completely abolished the CGRP-induced increase of I(Ca.L). Although the effects of CRGP were similar to those of isoproterenol, propranolol, a beta-adrenergic receptor antagonist, did not affect the CGRP-induced increase of I(Ca.L). After I(Ca.L) had been maximally activated by isoproterenol (2-mu-M) or intracellular cyclic adenosine 5'-monophosphate (100-mu-M), CGRP failed to increase I(Ca.L). Acetylcholine antagonized the effects of CGRP on I(Ca.L). Unlike the effects on atrial cells, CGRP had no significant effects on the membrane currents of ventricular myocytes. Thes results indicate that CGRP increases I(Ca.L) via adenylate cyclase activation by binding to specific membrane receptors in cardiac atrial myocytes. Furthermore, CGRP receptors are expressed in atrial cells but probably not in ventricular cells.

SP: MINIST EDUC SCI & CULTURE JAPAN, KATO SCI FDN
ID: SUPERCONDUCTORS; MICROSCOPY; OXIDE
AB: To identify the cleavage plane in single-crystalline YBa2Cu3O6+x (YBCO) with x = 0.7, we have applied the Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) to the analysis of the surface elemental content in the in situ cleaved surface. It has been found that the cleavage occurs between the CuO2 and BaO planes and that the complete evaporation of oxygen atoms on the chain site occurs into vacuum at room temperature. A new AES analysis procedure has been proposed and fully exploited in studies of the cleavage plane in YBCO.

AB: Polyhedral single crystals of oxide superconductor YBa2Cu2Ox have been grown. The crystals obtained possess well-developed habits and have a thickness of 3.6 mm along the c-axis. The annealed crystals show a sharp superconductive transition at 91 K. The temperature dependence of resistivity is found to be metallic both in the ab- and c-directions. A marked anisotropy is observed in the resistive transition at T(c) under the applied magnetic field parallel or perpendicular to the c-axis.

CT: INTERNATIONAL WORKSHOP ON CHEMICAL DESIGNING AND PROCESSING OF HIGH-T(C) SUPERCONDUCTORS ( CHEM-HTSC )
SP: MINIST EDUC SCI & CULTURE JAPAN, KATO SCI FDN
ID: CRITICAL CURRENT-DENSITY; ION IRRADIATION; BA2YCU3O7-DELTA
AB: Some results obtained on irradiation effects on high-T(c) superconductors YBa2Cu3O7-x (YBCO) are reviewed from the viewpoint of its modification by particle-beam irradiation. The main features of the irradiation effects are J(c) enhancement by the introduction of pinning centers in low-fluence regions and degradation of T(c), J(c) and crystal structure in high-fluence regions. The critical fluence depends strongly upon the kind and the energy of the incident particle as well as irradiation temperature. The difference in irradiation effects among particles will be related to the structure and the characteristics of the irradiation defects.

ID: CU-O FILMS
AB: We have been developing a thermal plasma flash evaporation method and applied it to the preparation of high-T(c) superconducting (HTSC) films. This method is characterized by high-rate deposition under a highly oxydizing atmosphere, resulting in the in situ formation of highly oriented YBa2Cu3O7-x (YBCO) films with T(c) around 90 K. The fact that any twins have not been observed in the microstructure at this stage, suggests direct growth of orthorhombic YBCO without the tetragonal-to-orthorhombic (T-O) phase transformation in this method.

TI: PRESSURE-DEPENDENCE OF SUPERCONDUCTING TRANSITION-TEMPERATURE AND OF HALL CONSTANT IN HIGH-TC CU-OXIDE SUPERCONDUCTORS
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: The pressure derivative of T(c) in the hole-doped superconductors having relatively lower carrier concentration is shown to change the sign from positive to negative at a certain pressure with a maximum of T(c), while it is negative in the highly-doped ones, which is confirmed as a general feature in these compounds. The Hall constants of the samples YBa2Cu3O7, CaBaLaCu3O7-y, YBa2Cu4O8, Bi2Sr2CaCu2O8 and Tl2Ba2CuO6+y is found to increase by about 10%/GPa which is almost the same amount that estimated by Yamada et al. from the Madelung energy calculation for YBa2Cu4O8.

AU: FUJIMORI, A; NAMATAME, H
AF: FUJIMORI, A; NAMATAME, H
TI: DOPING DEPENDENCE OF THE ELECTRONIC-STRUCTURE OF SUPERCONDUCTING AND NONSUPERCONDUCTING OXIDES - HIGH-ENERGY SPECTROSCOPIC STUDIES
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: BAND-STRUCTURE; RESONANT-PHOTOEMISSION; ND2-XCEXCUO4; BAPB1-XBIXO3; TRANSITION
AB: The electronic structure of electron- and hole-doped of Cu, Bi, and related 3d-transition-metal oxides has been studied by photoemission spectroscopy. In every system, carrier doping induces new states within the band gap of the parent compound. These "mid-gap states" are distributed mainly below and above the Fermi level for electron and hole doping, respectively. At low doping levels, doped carriers are localized around the impurities or defects, whereas they become itinerant at high doping levels reflecting the first affinity level or ionization state of the parent compound. The electronic structure of superconducting oxides is characterized by the high mobility of itinerant carriers.

AU: LEE, P; NAGAOSA, N
AF: LEE, P; NAGAOSA, N
TI: NORMAL STATE PROPERTIES OF THE HIGH-TC OXIDES - A GAUGE-THEORY
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: VALENCE-BOND STATE
AB: A theory of the high-T(c) superconductors is developed based on the ideas of the resonating valence bond (RVB) state and the spin-charge separation in it. The gauge field is naturally introduced to ensure the local gauge invariance of the theory which is equivalent to the local constraint of no double occupation. The fluctuating gauge field gives rise to the inelastic scattering of the bosons and fermions. This effect together with the screening effect by the gauge field explains various anomalous normal state properties of the high-T(c) superconductors, e.g., T-linear resistivity and the doping dependence of the Hall constant, and reconcile the transport properties with the large fermi surface observed in the angle-resolved photo-emission experiments.
C1: UNIV TOKYO,DEPT APPL PHYS,TOKYO 113,JAPAN

TI: MATERIAL OVERVIEW OF HIGH-TC OXIDES
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: SUPERCONDUCTIVITY; SYSTEM
AB: Structures of the existing cuprate superconductors can be viewed as alternating stacks of conducting CuO2-sheets and insulating ionic layers(block layers). With a concept of the block layer, we review the classification and material design of CuO2-layer based superconductors and present the empirical diagram for the carrier-doping characteristics. Strong dependence of T(c) on the nominal metal valence (or filling parameter) in copper- and non-copper based oxide superconductors is pointed out.

TI: ULTRATHIN FILMS AND SUPERLATTICES OF HIGH-TC SUPERCONDUCTORS CONTROLLED IN THE UNIT-CELL SCALE USING RHEED OSCILLATIONS
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: YBA2CU3O7-X/PRBA2CU3O7-X SUPERLATTICES; GROWTH
AB: Isolated ultrathin films of YBa2Cu3O7-x (YBCO) on PrBa2Cu3O7-x (PrBCO) and YBCO/PrBCO superlattices were epitaxially grown on SrTiO3 by reactive coevaporation with measurement of reflection high energy electron diffraction (RHEED) specular intensity. X-ray diffraction profiles and cross sectional electron microscopic (TEM) observation reveal that the heterostructures are excellent crystallinity with no interface disorder and fit for the purpose of the study of superconductivity of the 1 unit-cell layer of YBCO. The 1 unit-cell layer of YBCO sandwiched between PrBCO layers exhibits a superconducting transition with the onset temperature at 70K and the zero resistance at 30K. A reduction of the onset temperature is found to be mainly due to a decrease of the hole carriers but not due to the absence of interlayer coupling. It was demonstrated that the 1 unit-cell layer of YBCO needed the overlayer of PrBCO to give rise to superconductivity. The overlayer of PrBCO may have the role of supply of carriers for the underlying YBCO layer. The resistive transition for the ultrathin YBCO layer below 4 unit-cells thick was independent of the magnetic field up to 10T applied parallel to the CuO2 layer.

TI: ANISOTROPY AND DISSIPATION IN THE MIXED STATE OF HIGH-TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: YBA2CU3O7-DELTA SINGLE-CRYSTALS; ANGULAR DEPENDENT TRANSPORT; HIGH-TC SUPERCONDUCTORS; OXIDE SUPERCONDUCTORS; RESISTIVE TRANSITION; MAGNETIC-FIELD; BI2SR2CACU2O8+Y; FLUCTUATION; LATTICE; GROWTH
AB: Dissipative behavior of the flux line system in the mixed state of high temperature superconductors is studied. Difference in the magnitude of anisotropy between YBa2Cu3O7-y and Bi2Sr2CaCu2O8+y is manifest in the angular dependence of dissipation. An anomalous enhancement of disspation at high current densities is found for a narrow range of field angle near to the basal plane direction. Dissipation processes in the parallel and nearly parallel field configurations are discussed in the light of flux dynamics under the influence of strong pinning potential intrinsic to the layered structure.

TI: ROLE OF THE VALLEY DEGENERACY IN THE PLASMON MECHANISM OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY AND ITS IMPLICATION TO THE ALKALI-METAL-DOPED FULLERENE AXC60
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: We consider superconductivity in the multivalley electron gas without phonons by solving the full Eliashberg equation within the RPA which gives exact results in the limit of large valley degeneracy g(v) and is known to provide fairly good results even for g(v) almost-equal-to 3. We find s-wave superconductivity with the maximum T(c) over 80K. Superconductivity recently observed in A(x)C60 is explained from the standpoint of the electron gas with g(v) = 3.

TI: SUPERCONDUCTING PROPERTIES OF OXYGENATED LA2-XSRXCUO4+Y (O LESS-THAN-OR-EQUAL-TO X LESS-THAN-OR-EQUAL-TO 0.06)
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: Oxygenated La2-xSrxCuO4+y (0 less-than-or-equal-to x less-than-or-equal-to 0.06) has been examined by means of X-ray powder diffraction and resistivity. All samples prepared under high oxygen pressure (Po2 = 360 atm, 600-degrees-C) showed the superconductivity. Oxygenated La2-xSrxCuO4+y (x less-than-or-equal-to 0.06) was identified by X-ray powder diffraction at 10 K to be a mixture of two orthorhombic phases with nearly identical structure. In comparison with non-superconducting La2-xSrxCuO4 prepared in flowing oxygen, it is concluded that the phase with the smaller orthorhombic strain is responsible for the superconductivity of oxygenated La2-xSrxCuO4+y.

TI: INTERCALATION OF BI2SR2CAN-1CUNOY WITH IODINE AND OTHER HALOGENS
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: Intercalation of iodine and bromine into polycrystalline (n = 1,2,3) and single crystal (n = 2) specimens of Bi2Sr2Can-1CunOy has been examined. Intercalation of iodine is accompanied by an expansion of the c-axis of approximately 0.7nm in all 3 systems, while, for n = 2, Br insertion leads to half this expansion. Susceptibility and resistivity measurements are discussed. An investigation of the Hall coefficient in an n = 2 crystal suggests a modest charge transfer to the CuO2 planes.

CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: INSULATOR
AB: A new technique for preparing V spinel oxides was found with using Li3VO4. Electronic properties of LixMg1-xV2O4 and LiTi2O4 were studied by dc resistivity, magnetic susceptibility and optical reflectivity. LiV2O4-delta (delta > 0) shows metallic conductivity and Curie-Weiss-like susceptibility, while LiV2O4 has 240-K transition which depends on the oxygen content. The reflectivity edge near 1.2 eV is almost independent of carrier concentration as was observed in La2-xSrxCuO4.

CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: A new non-Cu oxide superconductor Sr(Ln)-Nb-O system (Ln:La,Nd,Pr,Ce,Gd and Ho) has been found by the resistivity and magnetization measurements. The highest onset transition temperature is about 12K. Preliminary electron and X-ray diffraction experiments indicate that main phase (approximately 90%) in this system is (Sr1-xLnx)Nb2O6-delta and another impurity phase (approximately 10%) is (Sr1-xLnx)2Nb2O7-delta, suggesting that the basic crystal structure is probably an oxygen deficient CaTa2O6 type structure.

CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: We report new, ultra high precision measurements of the electron-positron momentum spectra of YBa2Cu3O7-x and La1.874Sr.126CuO4. The YBCO experiments were performed on twin free, single crystals and show discontinuities with the symmetry of the Fermi surface of the CuO chain bands. Conduction band and underlying features in LSCO share the same symmetry and can only be separated with the aid of LDA calculations.

TI: STM STS STUDY OF SINGLE CRYSTALLINE BI2SR2CACU2OY (1) - SUPERCONDUCTING GAP AND BARRIER WIDTH DEPENDENCE OF TUNNELING SPECTRUM
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: Atomic resolution STM/STS has been performed on the cleaved surface (BiO layer) of Bi2Sr2CaCu2Oy at cryogenic temperatures down to 4.2K. The STM image taken at 4.2K clearly demonstrated atomic corrugations of Bi atoms, securing the vacuum tunneling in the present experiment. Based on the spectroscopic measurements, it was concluded that the BiO layer is essentially insulative with an energy gap. However, superconducting gap structure was often observed, possibly reflecting the electronic nature of CuO2 layer. Furthermore, it was found that the barrier height is an important factor determining the shape of the tunneling spectrum.

TI: STM STS STUDY OF SINGLE CRYSTALLINE BI2SR2CACU2OY (2) - ELECTRONIC NATURE OF THE BIO LAYER AS A FUNCTION OF OXYGEN-CONTENT
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: PHOTOEMISSION; BI2CASR2CU2O8; PLANE
AB: The electronic nature of the BiO layer in Bi2Sr2CaCu2Oy was studied as a function of oxygen content by STM/STS at room temperature and cryogenic temperatures down to 4.2 K. The conductance (dI/dV) vs V curve taken on the cleaved surface exhibited relatively large energy gap of approximately 0.1 eV, but no BCS-like peak was observed. This result suggests that the BiO layer is essentially insulative even below Tc. Furthermore, the specimens annealed under oxidized atmosphere tended to show metallic tunneling behavior. It seems that the incorporation of oxygen content in the BiO layer increases the density of states in the vicinity of the Fermi level.

CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: We investigated the LTO --> LTT transition occurring in La1.875Ba0.125CuO4 by synchrotron x-ray diffraction using two powder samples prepared by different techniques. The profile analysis of some hk0 and 001 reflections showed that the transition is very sensitive to the microstructure and that the strain release plays an important role in driving the LTO --> LTT transition.

TI: SUPERCONDUCTING, ELECTRONIC AND MAGNETIC-ANOMALIES DUE TO STRUCTURAL TRANSITION AROUND X=0.12 IN LA2-XBAXCUO4
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: PHASE
AB: From anomalies of the heat capacity and the thermal expansion, the structural phase boundary of the LTT-LTO transition is determined in the narrow range around x = 0.12 of La2-xBaxCuO4, where superconductivity is suppressed remarkably. The widely-spread Cu-NQR spectra and the decay of the asymmetry parameter of mu-SR are indicative of the magnetic order of Cu moments in the LTT phase where the induced charge transfer between Cu and O atoms causes the localization of the electronic state and the increase of magnetic moments at the Cu site.

TI: SUPERCONDUCTIVE-CONJUGATE PHOTOCONDUCTIVITY OF ND2CU1O4
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: SPECTRAL PHOTOCONDUCTIVITY; CU-O; ELECTRONS
AB: Transport phenomena of photocarriers have been studied in single crystals of Nd2Cu1O4 over the temperature range from 1.6K to 300K. Experimental results indicate an emergence of anomalous photoconductivity Q(T, lambda) below 40K and reach a step at 25K in correspondence with high Tc. This is another example of "superconductive-conjugate photoconductivity". Results of magneto-photoconductivity experiments suggest that dominant photo-carriers are likely to be electrons in a spherical conduction band, highly probably, the Cu(3d)-(4s) band.

ID: SPECTRAL PHOTOCONDUCTIVITY; CU-O
AB: A new series of insulators relevant to superconductors has been studied on the Bi2(Sr2Ca1)1-x(La2Y1)xCu2Oz system over x = 0-1.0. Above x = 0.90, the material exhibits an onset with step temperatures of photoconductivity Q(T, lambda) at lambda = 400-650nm in accordance or correspondence with superconductive Tsc. Here, we introduce again a new concept of "superconductive-conjugate photoconductivity" in the Bi2(Sr2Ca1)1-x(La2Y1)xCu2Oz system.

TI: ELECTRON-PHONON INTERACTION ASSOCIATED WITH CU-O BOND INVESTIGATED BY RAMAN-SPECTROSCOPY
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: The Raman spectra of the single crystals of Ca1.8Sr0.2CuO3 with the Cu-O chain, La2CuO4 and YBa2Cu3O6 with the Cu-O2 plane have been investigated. In the spectra of ca1.8Sr0.2CuO3 and La2.CuO4, peaks have been observed at around 450, 500 and 700 cm-1 with strong second-order features in addition to Raman-allowed A mode phonon peaks. In YBa2Cu3O6, a broad peak has been observed at around 1300 cm-1 due to two phonon scattering. They are ascribed to the zone-boundary phonons associated with the motions of oxygens in the Cu-O bond, which appear through the strong coupling of the electron-hole pair excited on the Cu-O bond with the corresponding vibrations.

AB: Optical spectra of Sr1-xLaxTiO3 have been investigated to unravel the change of electronic structures with varying the d-band filling parameter x (or Ti-valence, +4-x). In the small-x region (< 0.5), the apparent plasma frequency was observed to increase with x, supporting the simple picture of the d-band filling. As x further increases and approaches the end (x = 1), the deduced effective mass of d-electron was observed to be critically enhanced, indicating the increasing effect of electron correlation.

AB: Optical reflectivity of single crystals of the Bi-based Cu and Co oxides was measured and analyzed. The doping effects in the heavily doped region, the n-dependence, and the comparison between Cu and Co oxides are discussed. The optical spectra for various cuprates are compared in order to find a common feature of the superconducting CuO2 plane.

TI: OPTICAL CONDUCTIVITY IN PR2-XCEXCUO4-DELTA SINGLE-CRYSTALS - COMPARISON WITH THE CASE OF LA2-XSRXCUO4
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: REFLECTIVITY; YBA2CU3O7; GAP
AB: We have investigated spectra of optical conductivity for single crystals of Pr2-xCexCuO4-delta with varying x and delta. In comparison with La-Sr-Cu-O system, the growth of a 'Drude' part is observed to be much slower. It seems consistent with the difference of the electronic phase diagram between the two systems, La-Sr-Cu-O and Pr-Ce-Cu-O, where the metal-insulator transition occurs at x(c) approximately 0.06 and at x(c) approximately 0.14, respectively. Nevertheless, the spectral weight of charge transfer (CT) excitation of Pr2CuO4 is readily transferred to 'mid-IR' region with a small amount of Ce-substitution (x < x(c)) or oxygen defects. It indicates that the electronic state in the CuO2 sheets is seriously affected by electron-doping even though the compound remains to be an antiferromagnetic insulator. This investigation also indicates that oxygen deficiencies certainly introduces extra electron-carriers.

CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: VALENCE
AB: The electronic structure of the metallic but non-superconducting copper oxide La4BaCu5O13 and formally Cu3+ insulator NaCuO2 is studied by photoemission spectroscopy and cluster model calculations. As for La4BaCu5O13, a Fermi edge has been observed and the valence band and the Cu 2p core level spectra resemble those of Cu-oxide superconductors. From the analysis of the spectra of NaCuO2, the charge transfer energy-DELTA is found to be negative and the band gap is of a p-p type.

AB: By negative muon spin rotation method (mu-SR) the paramgnetic shifts of muonic oxygen, K-mu-, have been measured in the paramagnetic phase of YBa2Cu3O6; K-mu-is 4.6 +/- 1.9 x 10(-4) at 500 K and 8.7 +/- 1.7 x 10(4) at 550 K. In the normal state of the superconducting YBa2Cu3O7, GdBa2Cu3O7 and YBa2Cu3O6.5 K-mu-'s have not been determined due to a very fast mu- spin relaxation time, T2star. This mu-SR results in stoichiometric YBa2Cu3Ox makes a contarst with those in doped superconductor La2-xSrxCuO4-delta, in which T2star do not show any drastic change in superconducting and insulating phases.

AB: In order to investigate the internal field around the Ba atom in YBaCuO superconducting compounds, the time-differential perturbed angular correlation(TDPAC) experiments have been performed by means of a radioactive ion implantation technique. CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: The temperature dependence of the Cu-63 nuclear spin-lattice relaxation rate 1/T1 in Y0.925Ca0.075Ba2Cu4O8+delta (T(c) = 90K) has been measured between 4.2K and 340K by the nuclear quadrupole resonance(NQR) technique. In the normal state, although the behavior of 1/T1 with temperature is similar to the case of YBa2Cu4O8, the contribution of spin fluctuations in Y0.925Ca0.075Ba2Cu4O8+delta is smaller than that of YBa2Cu4O8. Therefore, the increase in T(c) upon substitution of Ca2+ for Y3+ can be understood by the increase in the hole concentration at the Cu-O2 plane and by the depression of the antiferromagnetic spin correlations.

CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: LA2-XSRXCUO4
AB: Magnitude SBAR of onsite Cu magnetic spin and temperature linear term gamma-T for La2-x(Sr,Ba)xCuO4 have been determined as a function of x by measuring the low temperature heat capacity below 1 K down to about 70 mK. At the insulator-superconductor boundary of both La-Sr and La-Ba systems, SBAR is about 0.4-mu-B that is about a half of the magnetic moment at x = 0. SBAR of La-Sr superconductor decreases with increasing x. The La-Ba system, however, shows a maximum of SBAR 0.25-mu-B and also shows a minimum of the electronic heat capacity at x approximately 0.12 where a conspicuous dip in T(c)-x phase diagram was observed.

CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: We have measured the temperature dependence of 1/T1 at the O, Cu T1 sites of Tl2Ba2CuOy. 1/T1 at the T1 sites does not follow the Korringa law for over-doped and superconducting specimens (4.2-300K). On the other hand, 1/T1 at the O and Cu sites appeared to be the Korringa type (T1xT = const) up to 200K for the over-doped specimen. From a comparison of the magnitude of 1/T1 at the O and Cu sites, we concluded that the antiferromagnetic spin fluctuation are playing essential role to the spin-dynamics at Cu site even in the over-doped state.

It has been found that the anisotropies in the Knight shifts along three principal directions are not dependent on both the temperature and the hole concentrations in the normal state and even in the superconducting (SC) state.

CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: We have examined the Cu2+ ESR signal with Bi2Sr2Ca1Cu2O8 and Bi2.2Sr2Ca0.8Cu2O8 samples. The pellets showed a weakly temperature-dependent chi-DC (the order of 10(-7) emu/g) with negative temperature coefficient. A large Curie-Weiss component, found in chi-DC of as-pulverized samples, disappeared upon subsequent annealing. For the annealed powders exhibiting intrinsic magnetism, a broad ESR signal appeared and chi-ESR of the 2212 phase had the same order of magnitude with chi-DC. We consider that Cu2+ spins (g approximately 2.1) are responsible for intrinsic susceptibility.

CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: Crystal potential of La2CuO4 for a positive muon is calculated by adding the atomic potentials of La, Cu and O atoms which are calculated by spin-dependent self-consistent atomic Shrodinger equation. We have found that the stable site for a positive muon is located in the interlayer region between two Cu-O planes. Dipolar field and hyperfine field of Cu and O spin are calculated at the muon sites. The calculated result shows that the hyperfine field from spin-polarized apical oxygen does contribute to the local field at the muon site and that the contact interaction of a positive muon is sensitive to the muon site and 2p orbital of apical oxygen.

TI: ELECTRICAL-CONDUCTION ACROSS CUO2 PLANES IN COPPER-OXIDE SUPERCONDUCTORS
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: STATE
AB: We have investigated the out-of-plane resistivity (rho-c) of a number of copper oxides with various carrier concentration systematically, using well-characterized single crystals. The out-of-plane conduction is strongly dependent on crystal structure, and in contrast to the metallic T-linear in-plane resistivity, rho-c is non-metallic in most superconducting compounds, suggesting an unconventional conduction mechanism. The most remarkable observation is that rho-c decreases with increasing carrier concentrations much more rapidly than rho-ab.

TI: PRESSURE EFFECT ON TC OF (YB0.7CA0.3)(BA0.8SR0.2)2CU3OZ WITH VARIOUS OXYGEN CONTENTS
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: TEMPERATURE
AB: Pressure dependence of T(c) for (Yb0.7Ca0.3)(Ba0.8Sr0.2)2Cu3Oz with different oxygen contents is investigated up to 2GPa. The pressure derivative dT(c)/dP shows decreasing positive values for the decreasing positive values for the region with (dT(c)/dp(pl)) > 0, and negative values for that with (dT(c)/dp(pl)) < 0: The sign and the magnitude of dT(c)/dP depend on the hole concentration in the CuO2 plane. These results indicate that the application of pressure plays a role of hole redistribution between the CuO chain and CuO2 plane sites.

CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: SUPERCONDUCTOR
AB: The pressure dependence of the Hall coefficient is studied for YBa2Cu4O8, YBa2Cu3O7, and Bi2Sr2CaCu2O8. The Hall coefficient decreases by approximately 8-12 %/GPa for these cuprates. The anomalous temperature dependence of the Hall coefficient is found to be intimately related with the occurrence of superconductivity.

TI: METAL-INSULATOR-TRANSITION IN 3D TRANSITION-METAL OXIDES WITH ABO3 AND A2BO4 TYPE STRUCTURES
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: 3d transition-metal oxides with perovskite and K2NiF4 crystal structures, (La,Sr)VO3, (La,Sr)FeO3, (La,Sr)CoO3, LaNiO3 and (La,Sr)2NiO4 systems are investigated focusing on the effect of carrier doping performed by the A-site ion substitution. Both (La,Sr)VO3 and (La,Sr)CoO3 systems show an insulator to metal transition by Sr substitution, however, the magnetic behavior differs drastically. The mid-infrared structure induced by Sr substitution is observed in the optical spectra of (La,Sr)2NiO4 system. Relation between the behavior of metal-insulator transition and the variation of the electronic and/or spin structure in these systems is discussed in comparison with the high-T(c) copper oxides.

TI: THE ORIGIN OF THE HUGE 1-F CONDUCTION NOISE IN HIGH-TC CUPRATES
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: The temperature dependence of the conduction noise was studied in the normal state of epitaxially grown films of high-T(c) cuprates Bi2Sr2Can-1CunOy (n=2, 3). We obtained the almost temperature-independent 1/f noise. The magnitude of the noise, which depends on the quality of the samples, still remains 5-6 orders of magnitude larger than in ordinary metals even in the samples with the highest quality. Possible origins are discussed both as an intragrain effect and other extrinsic effect.

TI: ELASTIC PROPERTIES OF SINGLE-CRYSTAL BI2.2SR1.8CACU2OY AS MEASURED BY A VIBRATING REED METHOD
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
ID: CA-CU-O; BI2SR2CACU2O8; INSTABILITY
AB: We have measured a discontinuity DELTA-dlnv(e)/dT congruent-to 7 ppm/K in Young's modulus sound velocity at T(c) = 83.8 K for single crystal Bi2.2Sr1.8CaCu2Oy. The anomaly is associated with the superconducting transition. We are not able to resolve any softening in DELTA-v(e)/v(e) at T(c) within our experimental resolution of better than 1ppm. This might indicate anisotropic stress dependence of T(c) as well as possible large quadratic coupling of stress to T(c). The position of an observed peak in the internal friction Q-1 at 145 K seems not to be directly related to superconductivity.

TI: INPLANE AND OUT-OF-PLANE THERMAL-CONDUCTIVITY OF LA2-XSRXCUO4 SINGLE-CRYSTALS
CT: 3RD INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY : HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: We report the first measurements of the in-plane and out-of-plane thermal conductivity (kappa-ab and kappa-c) for a series of La2-xSrxCuO4 single crystals grown by the traveling solvent floating zone method. Corresponding to the superconducting-nonsuperconducting transition between x = 0.20 and 0.30, a quantitative change is observed in both kappa-ab and kappa-c, indicating an enhanced electronic contribution and/or a change in the phonon-electron scattering. We also observed a sharp increase of thermal conductivity just below T(c) in both directions.

AB: Two dimensional spin-fermion model is studied by using the perturbation method and the spin wave approximation. Non-crossing diagrams are calculated using the dominant pole approximation. As a result, we see that the renormalization parameter z is reduced as z is-proportional-to L-1/4, where L is the linear dimension of the system, and the doped fermion becomes totally incoherent in the thermodynamic limit.

ID: LA2CUO4
AB: We investigate theoretically Cu 2p-XES for La2CuO4 and CuO on the basis of the formula of the second order optical process with the impurity Anderson model. According to Cu 2p-XES experiments so far made, a shoulder structure appears on the high energy side of the main peak in La2CuO4 and also in high-T(c) superconductors, but it is absent in CuO. It is shown that the appearance of the shoulder structure originates from the stronger hybridization for the a1g symmetry states in La2CuO4 than in CuO due to the existence of the apical oxygen.

ID: MODEL
AB: Taking the t-J model as the model of cupper-oxide high-Tc superconductors, we study the mechanism of superconductivity. The antiferromagnetic coupling generates attractive force between nearest-neighbor holes. We review the derivation of mean-field theory of hole-pairs. The resulting gap equation is analyzed at zero temperature in three spatial dimensions, showing the in-plane superconductivity.

CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
ID: II SUPERCONDUCTORS; TYPE-2 SUPERCONDUCTORS; ORDER PARAMETER; ELASTIC ENERGY; MAGNETIC-FIELD; FLUX LINES; INDUCTIONS; STATE
AB: A new theoretical framework to treat the thermal fluctuations of the Abrikosov vortex line lattice is presented. The effective free energy to describe the low energy fluctuations is derived which concludes the same elastic modes as those derived by Brandt on one hand and the phase fluctuation mode around the vortices on the other hand. The existence of the superconducting long range order in the Abrikosov vortex line lattice is discussed from a new view point by examining the asymptotic behavior of the gauge invariant correlation function.

TI: 2-DIMENSIONAL HUBBARD-MODEL IN LOW ELECTRON-DENSITY LIMIT
CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
ID: SCATTERING; STATE
AB: The two dimensional Hubbard model with repulsive interaction is studied in the t-matrix approximation. At T = 0 the particle-particle correlation function and the t-matrix are obtained analytically so that it is shown that the t-matrix and hence the self-energy have no singularities in the upper half plane of the complex energy variable. The phase angle of the t-matrix, delta(2k(F) + q,omega), in the limit q --> 0 and omega --> 0, is found to depend on the ratio omega/q and is not always zero. This non-vanishing phase angle results in the logarithmic correction to the imaginary part of the self-energy as Im-SIGMA(k(F),epsilon) infinity epsilon-2 ln parallel-to epsilon parallel-to. However, the renormalization factor Z is finite at the Fermi surface suggesting that the stability of the Fermi liquid state at least within the conventional perturbation theory. The case of the attractive interaction has also been studied and the crossover from the Copper pairing to the real-space pairing is indicated.

AU: HATSUGAI, Y; KOHMOTO, M
AF: HATSUGAI, Y; KOHMOTO, M
TI: EXACTLY SOLVABLE MODEL FOR CORRELATED LATTICE FERMIONS IN ANY DIMENSIONS
CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
AB: We present an exactly solvable Hamiltonian which consists of nearest neighbor hopping and infinite range interaction. The ground state and the thermodynamic quantities are analytically given in any dimensions. When the interaction is repulsive, the Luttinger's theorem breaks down. At half filling, we explicitly show the metal-insulator transition when the strength of the interaction is varied. At other fillings, the system is always metallic. When the interaction is attractive, the ground state is composed of pairs of electrons with opposite spins. The low energy excitations, however, is not a particle-hole type but a pairwise excitation across the Fermi surface.

AB: The dynamical spin susceptibility, chi(q -->, omega), of the t - J model on a square lattice has been studied based on a mean field (MF) approximation within the slave-boson (SB) formalism. We found that T1T has a minimum at T = (0.1 approximately 0.2)J and that Imchi(q -->, omega) at q --> = Q --> = (pi, pi) has a gap like structure as a function of omega if the temperature is low. These theoretical results indicating an apparent spin gap are consistent with experimental observations.

TI: LOW-SPIN TO HIGH-SPIN TRANSITION AT THE ONSET OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY IN LA-SR-CU-O AND HIGH-SPIN STATE IN ND-CE-CU-O COMPOUND
CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
ID: LA2-XSRXCUO4
AB: Electronic structures of La-Sr-Cu-O and Nd-Ce-Cu-O compounds are investigated by first principles cluster calculations. In the hole-doped CuO6 cluster embedded in La-Sr-Cu-O, the ground state changes from low spin to high spin state near the doping concentration of the onset of superconductivity, owing to the effect of the apical oxygens. If we take account of the effect of the dopant divalent ions by the virtual crystal approximation, the high spin state becomes more stable. While in the electron-doped CuO4 cluster in Nd-Ce-Cu-O, the high spin ground state always appears. Using these results, the observed phase diagrams for hole and electron-doped superconductors are explained.

ID: PROXIMITY
AB: The Josephson current induced by the proximity effect is studied for the SNS junction with the mesoscopic Aharonov-Bohm ring in the normal region. The results shows that the critical current has a component with hc/e oscillation in addition to hc/2e oscillation, the former of which is particular to the mesoscopic system. The relative intensity of these two oscillation will be discussed for various cases.

CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
ID: CUO2 LAYER
AB: Superconductivity in the system near charge transfer instability is investigated for CuO2 layer structure. By treating the transfer between Cu and O perturbatively, the effective interaction of O holes is derived and the possible symmetries of superconductivity is studied. The critical temperatures of superconductivity are estimated as a function of the doping rate, delta, based on weak-coupling approximation and are found to have characteristic delta-dependences depending on symmetry. We also examined the possible ground states with n = 1, 2, 3 or 4 holes for a wide range of the Coulomb repulsions on Cu sites and O sites.

TI: THEORY OF THE HALL-EFFECT IN THE NORMAL STATE OF COPPER-OXIDE SUPERCONDUCTORS
CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
ID: LA2-XSRXCUO4
AB: The anomalous temperature and concentration dependences of the Hall effect observed for La2-xSrxCuO4 are clarified theoretically, extending the electronic structure recently derived by Kamimura and Eto to a periodic system. The calculated results can explain satisfactorily all the observed anomalous behaviors of the Hall effect including the sign change. Furthermore the cotangent of the Hall angle is predicted to be proportional to T2. It is shown that the origin of anomalous behaviors of the Hall effect is due to the warped shape of the Fermi surface.

ID: TC CU-OXIDES; LAYER
AB: Electronic states of the d-p model and its effective Hamiltonian are investigated numerically on a small cluster. The latter has been derived by the assumption that Cu++ is stable against doping. It turns out that for standard set of parameters the effective Hamiltonian reproduces semi-quantitatively various physical properties, such as spin correlation and energy spectrum, of the original d-p model. In the effective Hamiltonian an appreciable attractive force appears between two O-holes around the same Cu site near the charge-transfer instability, whose validity is critically studied.

TI: LORENTZ-FORCE INDEPENDENT ENERGY-DISSIPATION IN THE MIXED STATE IN BI2SR2CACU2OY
CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
ID: HIGH-TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: Power-law current-voltage characteristics were observed at 80 K in the mixed state in Bi2Sr2CaCu2Oy single crystals with magnetic field applied perpendicular to the c-axis, where dissipation occurs independent of the Lorentz-force. The power-law exponent decreased sharply up to 2 T, at which point it becomes nearly constant. This behavior suggests an abrupt cross-over to a different dissipation mechanism. These features of the Lorentz-force independent dissipation can be consistently explained by a model which is based on two-dimensional vortex-antivortex pair breaking.

TI: THE 1ST MAGNETIC PENETRATION FIELD IN BSCCO SINGLE-CRYSTALS, TEMPERATURE-DEPENDENCE AND ELECTRON-IRRADIATION EFFECT
CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
AB: We report measurements of the first magnetic penetration field, Hp, of Bi2.2Sr1.8CaCu2O8+partial derivative crystals by a novel local Hall probe technique. We demonstrate that H(p) is slightly enhanced above the thermodynamic lower critical field, H(c1), by the Bean-Livingston surface barrier, and that irreversible magnetization at temperatures between 50K and T(c) (87.8K) arises mainly from the presence of this barrier. We argue that the non-linear temperature variation of H(p) observed, results from a temperature-dependent efficiency of the Bean-Livingston barrier.

ID: FIELD
AB: The temperature dependence of the ab-plane penetration depth lambda-ab and the lower critical field H(c1)ab in single crystals of Bi2(Sr,Ca)3Cu2Oy were measured by a radio-frequency method. A definite deviation from the BCS temperature dependence was observed at low temperatures, both in lambda-ab(T) and H(c1)ab(T). In particular d-lambda-ab = lambda-ab(T) - lambda-ab(0) is proportional to T2 at low temperatures. Neither the existence of weak links nor the distribution of H(cl) is likely to be the origin of the observed deviation, and the T2 behavior would have an intrinsic origin.

TI: ANISOTROPIC SUSCEPTIBILITY IN THE NORMAL STATE AND SUPERCONDUCTING FLUCTUATION-INDUCED DIAMAGNETISM OF SINGLE-CRYSTAL LA2-XSRXCUO4
CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
AB: Magnetic susceptibility of single-crystal La2-xSrxCuO4 with various x was measured with a SQUID magnetometer. The susceptibility with magnetic field (H) perpendicular to the CuO2 plane is 1.5 approximately 3 times as large as that with H parallel to the CuO2 plane, whereas they have similar temperature dependence. The field-dependent susceptibility in the vicinity of T(c) was also studied. From these data, T(c)(H), i.e., the field dependence of T(c) for H normal to the CuO2 plane, was determined by a new method. The coherence length at 0 K in the CuO2 plane estimated from T(c)(H) is about 30 angstrom for the samples of x = 0.12, 0.14 and 0.19.

AB: The perturbation series for the three dimensional free energy of Ginzburg-Landau model in a random potential is investigated for a strong magnetic field. The shift of the melting temperature of vortex lattice caused by the white noise random potential is evaluated. The crossover between the ''vortex-glass'' phase and the ''gauge-glass'' phase is discussed for a strong disorder.

AB: Thin films of Bi2Sr2Can-1Cu(n)Oy (n = 1 approximately 4) were prepared in situ by molecular beam epitaxy. All films were grown with a sequential deposition technique in an identical condition. To investigate the n dependence of physical properties, Hall coefficient and electron energy loss spectroscopy were measured. Hall coefficient and energy loss spectra were systematically changed from n = 1 to 3, but the results of the n = 4 phase showed different behavior.

CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
AB: The basic property of the superconducting superlattice is investigated, where finite supercurrent is flowing perpendicularly to the layer. The energy spectrum of the quasiparticle state in the superconducting superlattice is strongly influenced by the lattice period and the pair potential phase increment phi over one period. If the unit period is short, the phi dependence of the supercurrent is much different from that of the S-N-S junction observed so far. By the microwave irradiation, this feature will be seen more clearly.

CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
ID: HIGH-TC SUPERCONDUCTORS; CREEP
AB: Magnetic hysteresis loops of Bi2.2Sr1.8CaCu2O8+partial derivative crystals were measured using a local Hall probe magnetometer (LHPM). In particular we investigated the second hump of the magnetic hysteresis curve which appears suddenly at low temperature (below 35K) in our crystals. After moderate irradiation damage, produced by 2.5MeV electrons at low temperature, this hump was strongly enhanced and shifted to lower magnetic fields. This observation points to a change in flux creep dynamics as the origin of the second hump.

AB: Magnetization measurement was performed on stacked samples of Bi2Sr2CaCu2O8 single crystals with magnetic field applied along the stacking direction, being parallel to the crystal c-axis. This configuration with varying sample size within the ab-plane, made possible an accurate determination of the field dependence of the critical current density J(c) (parallel-to ab-plane) at temperatures below 30 K. However, the size-dependent magnetization hysteresis was found to vanish at higher temperatures, suggesting either a surface barrier or granularity of the crystals becomes a dominant factor for the observed irreversibility.

CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
AB: Effect of 28 MeV electron irradiation was investigated on the critical current density (J(c)) of high-T(c) superconductor Bi2Sr2CaCu2Oy single crystal grown by floating zone method. For the single crystal sample irradiated with a fluence between 3.4 x 10(17) cm-2 and 2.3 x 10(18) cm-2, J(c) was enhanced at temperatures from 4.2 to 40 K below 8 T in magnetic field parallel to c-axis of the crystal. Enhancement ratio in J(c) by irradiation increased with increasing fluence below 40 K, while at 60 K it has a maximum value with a fluence of 1.2 x 10(18) cm-2. The maximum value 80 was attained in enhancement ratio of J(c) at 40 K and 0.3 T.

AB: Irradiation effects of 2.5MeV He+ ion, 2.5MeV O+ ion, 2.5MeV Ni2+ ion and 1MeV Ar+ ion were studied on thin films of high-T(c) oxide superconductor YBa2Cu3O(x)(YBCO). In high fluence region, superconductivity and crystal structure were degraded by irradiation. Critical fluence, which is the fluence giving 0.1% increase in c-axis lattice constant was found to vary with the kind of incidental ions. In the irradiation of the four kinds of ions, the critical fluence had a tendency to decrease with increase in mass of ions.

AB: We report anisotropic critical current densities J(c)ab-plane(H parallel-to c) and J(c)c-axis(H parallel-to ab) of (La0.93Sr0.07)2Cu2O4 determined by magnetization measurements on a single crystal having a large dimension along both the a- and c-axes. At 4.2 K under low fields, J(c)ab(H parallel-to c) was approximately 10 times larger than J(c)c(H parallel-to ab), while the former showed much stronger field and temperature dependences. The field dependence of J(c)ab was found to obey the scaling law governed by the intrinsically small values of the irreversibility field B(c2)* (H parallel-to c). Our B(c2)* values agreed well with those determined by the onset of resistivity in electrical measurements.

CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
ID: MAGNETIC-PROPERTIES; COMPOUND; CERUSN3
AB: Specific heat experiments have been performed on the heavy fermion CeRuSnx (x = 3.0 and 2.91) in the temperature range between 30 mK and 4 K. For CeRuSn2.91, the specific heat data shows the second order type peak at 1.2 K which indicates a long-range antiferromagnetic transition. The entropy curve of CeRuSn3.0 indicates an existence of the metamagnetic transition which occurs at 3.5 T below 0.1 K from the heavy fermion to a magnetic state.

TI: EXPERIMENTAL STUDIES OF 3 SUPERCONDUCTING STATES IN THE ORGANIC SUPERCONDUCTOR BETA-(BEDT-TTF)2I3
CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
AB: The title compound has been regarded as a two-phase superconductor whose low-T(c) (1.4K) state is stable at ambient pressure and the high-T(c) one (8.0K) under high pressures. By structural, electrical and magnetic studies, it is found that it has three superconducting states all of which can be derived at ambient pressure by annealing at 100K for a few days. The high-T(c) state is verified to be the most stable one even at ambient pressure.

CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
AB: An x-ray photoemission study of (DMe-DCNQI)2Cu is reported. The line-shape analysis reveals the mixed valency of Cu+ and Cu2+, and the Cu+:Cu2+ ratio is found to be approximately 2:1. This suggest that Cu is in a valance fluctuating state in the metallic state and, in other (DCNQI)2Cu compounds, a Cu+-Cu2+ charge-ordering takes place below the metal-insulator transition temperature.

AB: A susceptibility increase and an anomalous lattice-parameter change are found in (DMeDCNQI)2Cu below 100 K. CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
AB: The commensurability effect of magnetoresistance anisotropy found in the quasi-one-dimensional organic superconductor (TMTSF)2X is explained in terms of the resonant drift motion of electrons in the field direction. This is the common picture with the model for the angular dependent magnetoresistance oscillation effect observed in the quasi-two-dimensional organic superconductors (BEDT-TTF)2X.

CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON MATERIALS AND MECHANISMS OF SUPERCONDUCTIVITY HIGH TEMPERATURE SUPERCONDUCTORS 3
AB: We have measured photoemission spectra of BaPb1-xBixO3 and extracted new information about their electronic structure. O 2p non-bonding states are located around the top of the valence band and possibly form the metallic states at the Fermi level. O 2p-Bi 6s anti-bonding states are located around 1 eV below the Fermi level forming a gap or pseudogap in Bi substituted samples, and their bonding counterpart is located both at around 6 and 10 eV corresponding to the splitting of the anti-bonding states.

AB: The physical properties of Ba1-xKxBiO3 including transport coefficients, optical spectra, Raman spectra, the upper critical field and superconducting energy gap were measured on thin films. AU: NORMAND, B; LEE, PA; NAGAOSA, N
AF: NORMAND, B; LEE, PA; NAGAOSA, N
TI: GAUGE-FIELD INTERACTION AND SUPERCONDUCTIVITY IN THE T'-J MODEL
AB: In a theory of dilute fermionic holes in a 2-dimensional antiferromagnet in the disordered state, the interparticle interactions can be cast in terms of a gauge field. We have calculated the gauge-field propagator D(R)(q,omega) at zero temperature, taking into account both fermionic and bosonic degrees of freedom. Numerical computations of the interaction spectra function show it to be dominated by the fermion contribution, and to have an unconventional power-law dependence alpha-2 F(omega) approximately omega-x, with x close to 1/3. Superconductivity in the model is expressed in the formalism of Eliashberg theory, with the unusual alpha-2 F(omega).

AU: KOHNO, H; YAMADA, K
AF: KOHNO, H; YAMADA, K
TI: FERMI-LIQUID ANALYSIS OF THE NORMAL PHASE
ID: HALL; SUPERCONDUCTIVITY; SYSTEMS
AB: We demonstrate that it is quite natural to describe the normal phase of copper-oxide superconductors as a Fermi liquid, by explaining qualitative behaviours of nuclear spin-lattice relaxation rate T1(-1), electrical resistivity and Hall coefficient. On the basis of a microscopic model composed of d- and p-electrons, we derive the rigorous expressions for the specific heat, spin susceptibility, T1 and T2-term of electrical resistivity. By insisting consistency among these quantities, it is concluded that spin fluctuations localized in momentum space are essential and sufficient to explain their unusual behaviours observed in the light-doping region of holes, while spin fluctuations become extended as the doping rate increases. We also attempt to explain the temperature-dependent Hall coefficient by developing the Fermi-liquid theory of anomalous Hall effect due to skew scattering.

ID: SINGLE-CRYSTALS; SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: Field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) magnetization curves were measured for the single crystals of YBa2Cu3O7 and (La1-xSrx)2CuO4 (x = 0.065) under several magnetic fields. Using the extended Bean's critical state model, J(c) and lower critical field H(c1)(0) were estimated as fitting parameters to explain FC and ZFC curves consistently. The J(c)(T) values thus obtained well agreed with the reported ones obtained by the other method.

TI: JOSEPHSON CURRENT THROUGH NARROW CHANNELS
AB: The supercurrent through a constriction is calculated both numerically and analytically for two-dimensional superconductor-semiconductor-superconductor Josephson junctions. It is found that the critical current changes stepwise as a function of the width due to the quantization of the transverse momentum in the constriction. The step height of the critical current depends both on the gap of the superconductors and on the separation between the two super-normal interfaces.

AU: KANEKO, K
AF: KANEKO, K
TI: GLOBALLY COUPLED CIRCLE MAPS
ID: SPATIOTEMPORAL CHAOS; DYNAMICAL-SYSTEMS; VISUAL-CORTEX; INTERMITTENCY; DIFFUSION; LATTICES; OSCILLATORS; ATTRACTORS; TURBULENCE; PATTERNS
AB: A network of circle maps is investigated. Successive transitions are found among coherent, ordered, partially ordered (PO), and turbulent phases. In the ordered phase, two-cluster attractors with similarity have a large basin volume, which are reduced to a unique circle map through a scaling transformation with two parameters. The PO phase is characterized by the increase of partition complexity. In the phase, chaotic itinerancy is observed, whose dynamics consists of quasistationary high-dimensional chaotic motion, low-dimensional attractor ruins, and switching among them. Dependence of the diffusion constant on the size and the nonlinearity clearly deviates from that by a random phase approximation. suggesting remaining correlation among elements. even in the turbulent phase.

AU: LIU, Y
AF: LIU, Y
TI: A NONLINEAR DIFFUSION SYSTEM ON THE DISCRETE SPACE-TIME LATTICE - AS A SIMPLE-MODEL FOR MIGRATION PROCESSES
ID: SPATIOTEMPORAL CHAOS; POPULATIONS
AB: A new nonlinear discrete diffusion model describing migration processes of biological population is proposed, and its dynamical behaviours are studied. Stochastic and deterministic versions are compared, and deterministic chaos is found to be suppressed by stochasticity. Curious motions of domain walls in one- and two-dimensional lattices are observed. Localized spatiotemporal chaos is found both in one- and two-dimensional lattices.

AF: SATAKA, M; KAWATSURA, K; NARAMOTO, H; NAKAI, Y; YAMAZAKI, Y; KOMAKI, K; KUROKI, K; KANAI, Y; KAMBARA, T; AWAYA, Y; HANSEN, JE; KADAR, I; STOLTERFOHT, N
TI: HIGH-RESOLUTION L-SHELL AUGER-SPECTROSCOPY OF MG-LIKE SCANDIUM PRODUCED IN 89-MEV SC8+ +HE COLLISIONS
ID: SELECTIVE PRODUCTION; STATES; SPECTRA; ENERGY
AB: In 89-MeV Sc8+ + He collisions, the light target atom He was used to ionize selectively the 2p shell of the scandium projectile. The subsequent L-shell Auger emission from Mg-like Sc9+ was measured with high resolution using the method of zero-degree Auger spectroscopy. The spectra are dominated by three peak groups that are attributed to transitions from the various initial states belonging to the configuration 1s(2)2s(2)2p(5)3s(2)3p to the final states 1s(2)2s(2)2p(6)3s2S, 1s(2)2s(2)2p(6)3p2P, and 1s(2)2s(2)2p(6)3d2D. The 2P1/2-2P3/2 fine-structure splitting was resolved for the final configuration 1s(2)2s(2)2p(6)3p. The branching ratio for the transition to 1s(2)2s(2)2p(6)3d2D, which involves three electrons and, thus, must be ascribed to correlation, is compared to earlier results for the isoelectronic ions Al+ and Ar6+. Good agreement between observed and calculated branching ratios to the three final states is obtained by including only correlation in the initial state. A discrepancy for the branching to the 1s(2)2s(2)2p(6)3d2D term, which was observed already in the earlier investigation of Ar6+, has been removed by including correlation in the n = 2 shell in addition to the correlation in the n = 3 shell, which was the only correlation introduced previously.

AU: SHIN, S; TEZUKA, Y; SUGAWARA, A; ISHIGAME, M
AF: SHIN, S; TEZUKA, Y; SUGAWARA, A; ISHIGAME, M
TI: SILENT CENTRAL MODES OF THE SUPERIONIC CONDUCTOR LIKSO4 STUDIED BY MEANS OF HYPER-RAMAN SCATTERING - EVIDENCE OF COUPLING BETWEEN LITHIUM-ION CONDUCTION AND SULFATE-ION ROTATION
ID: TEMPERATURE PHASE-TRANSITIONS; POTASSIUM-SULFATE; DIFFRACTION; NEUTRON; MOTIONS; SPECTRA
AB: Relaxational central modes due to the rotational Brownian motion of the sulfate ions are measured by hyper-Raman scattering in LiKSO4 crystal. The B1-u relaxational mode is the rotational mode about the c axis. This is a silent mode, which is inactive for Raman and infrared measurements. The infrared-active E1-u relaxational modes are also found, which are the rotational modes about the a and b axes. Since the anisotropy of the Li+-ion conductivities is well elucidated by the ratio of B1-mu- and E1-mu-rotational relaxation times, the coupling between sulfate-ion rotation and Li+-ion migration is strongly supported. Relaxational central modes are also found in Raman scattering. A comparison between the Raman and hyper-Raman spectra shows that interactions between sulfate ions are strong in rotations about the a and b axes. However, they are weak for rotations about the c axis.

AU: HATSUGAI, Y; KOHMOTO, M
AF: HATSUGAI, Y; KOHMOTO, M
TI: NUMERICAL STUDY OF THE HIDDEN ANTIFERROMAGNETIC ORDER IN THE HALDANE PHASE
ID: ISOTROPIC HEISENBERG CHAIN; QUANTUM SPIN CHAINS; BOND GROUND-STATES; LONG-RANGE ORDER; ARBITRARY SPINS; MODEL; GAP; S=1; EXCITATIONS; FIELD
AB: We investigate the string correlation functions proposed by den Nijs and Rommelse for S = 1 Heisenberg antiferromagnets in one dimension. The Hamiltonian with D-SIGMA(i)(S(i)z)2 term is diagonalized by the Lanczos method to obtain the ground state. We calculate both the usual spin-spin correlation functions and the string correlation functions not only in the z direction (quantized direction) but also in the x direction to investigate the Z2 X Z2 symmetry breaking recently proposed by Kennedy and Tasaki. We find that the long-range string correlation, which is argued to exist in the Haldane disordered phase, in fact, exists at the Heisenberg point D = 0 by a finite-size analysis. We can show explicitly that the string correlation in the x direction signifies the difference between the Haldane phase and the Neel phase, which appears for the D < 0, \D\greater-than-or-similar-to 1) case. In the large-D (D greater-than-or-similar-to 1) phase, all spin-spin correlations are short ranged as expected. There is a significant enhancement in the usual and string correlations in the x direction at the boundary between the Haldane phase and the large-D phase.

AF: MIYATAKE, T; WADA, T; KOSUGE, M; YAEGASHI, Y; ICHINOSE, A; YAMAUCHI, H; KOSHIZUKA, N; MORI, N; TANAKA, S
TI: COMPOSITION DEPENDENCE OF THE PRESSURE EFFECT ON TC IN (YB0.7CA0.3)(BA0.8SR0.2)2CU3OZ
ID: SUPERCONDUCTING TRANSITION-TEMPERATURE; CA
AB: The effect of pressure on the superconducting transition temperature T(c) of (Yb0.7Ca0.3) (Ba0.8Sr0.2)2Cu3Oz, is investigated for oxygen contents z from z = 6.43 to z = 6.78. The pressure derivative dT(c)/dP shows decreasing positive values for the hole-concentration region where T(c) increases with the hole concentration in the CuO2 plane, p(pl) and negative constant values for the region where T(c) decreases with p(pl). The sign and magnitude of dT(c)/dP may be determined by not only the carrier type but also pressure-induced enhancements of both the hole concentration and intraplane coupling in the CuO2 plane.

AU: YOSHIDA, M; TAJIMA, S; KOSHIZUKA, N; TANAKA, S; UCHIDA, S; ISHIBASHI, S
AF: YOSHIDA, M; TAJIMA, S; KOSHIZUKA, N; TANAKA, S; UCHIDA, S; ISHIBASHI, S
TI: OPTICAL PHONONS OF CA1.8SR0.2CUO3 WITH THE CU-O CHAIN STRUCTURE
ID: RAMAN-SCATTERING; LA2CUO4; SUPERCONDUCTORS
AB: Raman and ir spectra of Ca1.8Sr0.2CuO3 with the Cu-O chain structure have been investigated. Scattering peaks due to Raman-allowed A(g)-mode phonons have been observed at 306 and 530 cm-1 at room temperature for the polarization of light along the a and c axes. On the other hand, when the polarization is along the b axis (chain direction), Raman-forbidden peaks have been observed at 235, 440, 500, and 690 cm-1 with strong second-order features, which show strong resonance enhancement at the charge-transfer gap energy of 2.0 eV. They are ascribed to the zone-boundary phonons, which appear through the strong coupling of the electron-hole pair excited on the Cu-O chain with phonons associated with the motion of atoms in the chain.

AU: IDO, T; MAGOSHI, K; EISAKI, H; UCHIDA, S
AF: IDO, T; MAGOSHI, K; EISAKI, H; UCHIDA, S
TI: OPTICAL STUDY OF THE LA2-XSRXNIO4 SYSTEM - EFFECT OF HOLE DOPING ON THE ELECTRONIC-STRUCTURE OF THE NIO2 PLANE
ID: TRANSITION; TRANSPORT
AB: The optical spectra of La2-xSrxNiO4 are systematically investigated from the infrared to ultraviolet energy range and over a wide compositional range, 0 less-than-or-equal-to x less-than-or-equal-to 0.5. La2NiO4 is a charge-transfer (CT) insulator with a CT energy gap of about 4 eV, twice as large as that in the isostructural La2CuO4. Introduction of holes into the NiO2 plane induces broad absorption in the infrared region below the CT gap energy, similar to the case of La2-xSrxCuO4. The induced absorption consists of two distinct bands centered at 0.6 and 1.5 eV. The total spectral weight of the two absorption bands increases proportionately to the dopant concentration x. Notable differences from the cuprates are that these bands do not shift with increasing x and that a Drude-type absorption centered at omega = 0 does not appear up to x = 0.5 in the case of the nickelate. They might arise from different symmetries of the doped holes and/or different spin quantum number of the Ni2+ ion.

TI: CORRELATION LENGTH AND FREE-ENERGY OF THE S = 1/2 XXZ CHAIN IN A MAGNETIC-FIELD
ID: THERMAL BETHE-ANSATZ; DIMENSIONAL HEISENBERG-FERROMAGNET; CRITICAL-BEHAVIOR; LOW-TEMPERATURE; TRANSFER-MATRIX; MODEL; SYSTEMS; RING
AB: The correlation length and the free energy of the S = 1/2 XXZ chain in a magnetic field in the z direction are calculated with use of a set of equations for a series of infinite numbers. These are derived by the Bethe-ansatz method for the quantum transfer matrix. The equations for free energy should be equivalent to the thermodynamic Bethe-ansatz nonlinear integral equations. A numerical method that calculates precisely the free energy and the correlation length is given.

AU: HIRENZAKI, S; TOKI, H; YAMAZAKI, T
AF: HIRENZAKI, S; TOKI, H; YAMAZAKI, T
TI: (D, HE-3) REACTIONS FOR THE FORMATION OF DEEPLY BOUND PIONIC ATOMS
AB: We have studied theoretically the proton pick-up (d,He-3) reactions leading to deeply bound pionic atoms. The forward scattering cross sections for an incident energy T(d) = 600 MeV have been calculated using the effective number approach for the Pb-208 target nucleus. It was found that the pionic 2p state has the maximum cross section among all calculated states. We conclude that (d,He-3) reactions produce pionic atoms in a detectable manner.

AU: MIDORIKAWA, S; HONDA, M; KASAHARA, K
AF: MIDORIKAWA, S; HONDA, M; KASAHARA, K
TI: MASSES OF NEUTRINOS SUGGESTED FROM THE ANOMALOUS ATMOSPHERIC NEUTRINO FLUX
ID: OSCILLATIONS; MATTER; TIME
AB: The atmospheric neutrino data taken by the Kamiokande and IMB-3 detectors are analyzed using various models for the fluxes. A translation formula is derived to compare different experiments and/or flux models. It is found that three-neutrino oscillations can explain both results consistently. If one neutrino-mass-squared difference dominantly determines the oscillations, it is greater than 1 x 10(-4) eV2 at the 1-sigma-level almost independent of the specific model. From neutrino-induced down-going events at Kamiokande, a more stringent lower bound of 2 x 10(-3) eV2 is obtained at the 1-sigma-level.

AU: SHIMOMURA, Y
AF: SHIMOMURA, Y
TI: LARGE EDDY SIMULATION OF MAGNETOHYDRODYNAMIC TURBULENT CHANNEL FLOWS UNDER A UNIFORM MAGNETIC-FIELD
ID: NUMERICAL-SIMULATION; STATISTICAL-ANALYSIS; REYNOLDS-NUMBER; STRESS; MODEL
AB: Magnetohydrodynamic turbulent channel flows under a uniform magnetic field are studied by using a large eddy simulation technique. The effect of a uniform magnetic field is incorporated into the subgrid-scale model in the form of a local damping factor. Compared with the experiment, this model is shown to work better than the usual Smagorinsky model in both turbulent and laminar states. This model predicts the detailed structures of the present flows, for which, one-point global turbulence models of ensemble mean type are helpless.

AU: ICHIKAWA, T; SYONO, K
AF: ICHIKAWA, T; SYONO, K
TI: TOBACCO GENETIC TUMORS
DE: AUXIN; CYTOKININ; NICOTIANA; ONCOGENE; ROL GENE; TUMOR
ID: PLANT-TISSUE CULTURES; T-DNA; NICOTIANA-GLAUCA; CROWN-GALL; CYTOKININ; AUXIN; INDUCTION; LANGSDORFFII; CALLUSES; PLASMID
AB: Tobacco genetic tumors developed spontaneously from hybrid plants that are derived from sexual or somatic crosses between two species of Nicotiana. Thus, genomic transformation by T-DNA, as occurs in cases of crown galls and hairy roots, is not indispensable for the initiation of such genetic tumors. Tumorization may be attributable to expression of certain genomic genes that are highly homologous to those of the T-DNA of Ri-plasmids, with subsequent overproduction of phytohormones and/or to elevation in sensitivity to endogenously supplied phytohormones of cells of the hybrids. Tumorization events occur sequentially after stimulation by stress, such as wounding.

AU: KAMIYA, Y; KOBAYASHI, M; FUJIOKA, S; YAMANE, H; NAKAYAMA, I; SAKURAI, A
AF: KAMIYA, Y; KOBAYASHI, M; FUJIOKA, S; YAMANE, H; NAKAYAMA, I; SAKURAI, A
TI: EFFECTS OF A PLANT-GROWTH REGULATOR, PROHEXADIONE CALCIUM (BX-112), ON THE ELONGATION OF RICE SHOOTS CAUSED BY EXOGENOUSLY APPLIED GIBBERELLINS AND HELMINTHOSPOROL .2.
DE: BIOLOGICAL ACTIVITY OF GIBBERELLINS; BX-112; ORYZA-SATIVA; PROHEXADIONE CALCIUM; SHOOT ELONGATION
ID: RETARDANT (E)-1-(4-CHLOROPHENYL)-4,4-DIMETHYL-2-(1,2,4-TRIAZOL-1-YL)-1-PENTEN-3-; BIOLOGICAL-ACTIVITIES; BIOASSAYS
AB: Prohexadione calcium (BX-112) is a novel plant growth regulator that inhibits the late stages of the biosynthesis of gibberellins in plants. Fourteen kinds of gibberellin, helminthosporol and helminthosporic acid were applied simultaneously with BX-112 to rice seedlings (Oryza sativa L. ), and their growth-promoting activities in terms of shoot elongation were examined. The growth-promoting activities of GA1, GA4, GA18, GA22, GA23, GA38, helminthosporol and helminthosporic acid were not inhibited by BX-112, but those of GA5, GA9, GA15, GA19, GA20, GA31, GA44 and GA53 were inhibited. These results suggest that 3-beta-hydroxylation is an important and necessary step in the biosynthesis of gibberellins that promote shoot elongation in rice seedlings. The weak promotion of shoot elongation by GA22 in the presence of BX-112 suggests that the effect of a hydroxyl group at C-18 of GA22 might be able to mimic the effect of the 3-beta-hydroxyl group of GA1. Helminthosporol and helminthosporic acid may promote the shoot elongation of rice by mimicking physiologically active gibberellins and not by stimulating their biosynthesis.

TI: EXPOSURE OF LEAVES OF CUCUMIS-SATIVUS L TO LOW-TEMPERATURES IN THE LIGHT CAUSES UNCOUPLING OF THYLAKOIDS .1. STUDIES WITH ISOLATED THYLAKOIDS
DE: ATPASE; CHILLING STRESS; CUCUMIS-SATIVUS L (CUCURBITACEAE); PHOTOSYNTHESIS; THYLAKOIDS; UNCOUPLING
ID: CHILLING-RESISTANT PLANTS; COUPLING FACTOR 1; PHOTOSYNTHETIC APPARATUS; ELECTRON-TRANSFER; SENSITIVE PLANTS; PHOTOSYSTEM-II; DARK STORAGE; CHLOROPLASTS; INACTIVATION; PROTEINS
AB: Chilling of leaves of cucumber (Cucumis sativus L.) at 5-degrees-C in moderate light for 5 h caused almost complete suppression of photosynthetic oxygen evolution in the leaves. Comparison of electron transport activities determined in the presence and absence of an uncoupler, methylamine, indicated that thylakoids prepared from such treated leaves were uncoupled without any significant changes in the capacity for electron transport. Immunoblotting revealed that the amount of coupling factor 1 (CF1) associated with membranes was reduced by the chilling treatment in the light. Thylakoids prepared from leaves that had been chilled in moderate light for 5 h and then rewarmed for 1 h were coupled and capable of synthesising ATP. However, the capacity of leaf photosynthesis was not restored by the rewarming. These results indicate that the thylakoids are uncoupled by the dissociation of some CF1 complexes from the thylakoid membranes during the chilling treatment of leaves in the light and that thylakoids are recoupled by reassociation of CF1 during the subsequent rewarming of the treated leaves at 25-degrees-C. It also appears that chilling in the light causes irreversible damage to reaction(s) other than those involved in electron transport and photophosphorylation.

TI: EXPOSURE OF LEAVES OF CUCUMIS-SATIVUS L TO LOW-TEMPERATURES IN THE LIGHT CAUSES UNCOUPLING OF THYLAKOIDS .2. NONDESTRUCTIVE MEASUREMENTS WITH INTACT LEAVES
DE: ATPASE; CHILLING STRESS; CUCUMIS-SATIVUS L (CUCURBITACEAE); PHOTOSYNTHESIS; THYLAKOIDS; UNCOUPLING
ID: CHLOROPHYLL FLUORESCENCE; MEMBRANE ENERGIZATION; PHOTOPHOSPHORYLATION; CHLOROPLASTS; INVITRO; INVIVO; P515
AB: To examine the effects of chilling of leaves of cucumber (Cucumis sativus L.) in moderate light on the coupling state of thylakoids in situ, changes in fluorescence, changes in light scattering and flash-induced changes in absorbance at 518 nm were examined in intact leaves. After chilling of leaves at 5-degrees-C in the light for 5 h, the non-photochemical quenching of fluorescence, a measure of energisation of thylakoids, was largely suppressed. The treatment also caused a suppression of light-induced changes in the light scattering by leaves, which depends on the formation of a pH gradient across thylakoid membranes. When thylakoids were prepared by very gentle methods from the leaves chilled in the light, through a step of preparation of intact chloroplasts, the transport of electrons from H2O to ferricyanide was uncoupled, being insensitive to an uncoupler, methylamine. These data provide consistent evidence that the thylakoids are uncoupled in situ by the chilling of leaves in the light and, as a consequence of the uncoupling, the energisation of the membranes is suppressed. However, the decay of the flash-induced change in absorbance at 518 nm in leaves was not markedly accelerated by the treatment. The thylakoids isolated from leaves chilled in the light, which were in the uncoupled state, also did not show a rapid decay, unless an efficient uncoupler such as gramicidin was added. These results suggest that even a considerable uncoupling of thylakoids, brought about by chilling of leaves in the light, is not sufficient to cause a marked acceleration of the decay of the flash-induced change in absorbance at 518 nm. Therefore, analysis at 518 nm is not always a sensitive method for assessing the coupling state of thylakoids.

TI: PURIFICATION AND PROPERTIES OF SPHERICAL VIRUS-PARTICLES ASSOCIATED WITH GRAPEVINE AJINASHIKA DISEASE
ID: PHLOEM
AB: Grapevine ajinashika associated virus (GAaV) was successfully purified from ajinashika-affected berry pulps by an enzyme treatment purification procedure. Virions were spherical (approximately 25 nm in diameter), sedimented as a single component of approximately 110S, had a buoyant density in CsCl of approximately 1.38 g/cm3, and had an estimated nucleic acid content of 30%. GAaV contained a single species of single-stranded RNA of an estimated 6.8 kb and a coat protein of 23,000 Da. GAaV was effectively detected in extracts of shoots and mature berries by immunosorbent electron microscopy (IEM) and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) using specific antiserum. Biological and physicochemical properties of GAaV were similar to luteoviruses. However, GAaV shared no serological relationships with barley yellow dwarf and potato leafroll viruses. Antisera of grapevine fanleaf virus and grapevine phloem-limited isometric virus (GPLIV) did not react with GAaV in IEM and double-diffusion tests. However, anti-GPLIV antiserum reacted with GAaV in protein A-gold labelling immunosorbent electron microscopy.
